(1) (a) Sentence with modal particle ‘le’ indicating change of state
Indicates that the situation is new — it didn’t used to be so, or you were waiting for it to be so. You’re saying that the situation has become true.
Note that this can sometimes be translated as “finally” or “now” without necessarily using explicit Chinese words for “finally” or “now".

So when do you use xiànzài? Xiànzài is the name of a specific time: “right now” or “at this time". The le that means “now” isn’t necessarily a specific time; it just means the situation has become true, but wasn’t true previously. Both ideas can appear in the same sentence, and both can be translated by English “now”, but they don’t necessarily mean the same thing.
1. “Is Chinese hard?” “I now think it’s not so hard.”
2. “How many children do the Wangs have?” “Two, both grown up now.”
3. “Are the apples spoiled?” “All 10 kilograms of apples that you bought are spoiled now.”
4. “Are there a lot of people who can speak Mandarin?” “There used to be very few; but now there are a lot.”
5. “How much does it cost to buy a small radio?” “They’re cheap now — $25 is enough.”
6. “Are you still hungry now?” “Not any more.”
b•ng. Negative “not any more", “not any longer"(sentences p. 87, 1b)

méiyªu le“there is none left”

This pattern is used to indicate a contrast between two different predicates:
S zh• Predicate1, bù Predicate2“S1 only/just Predicate1, but doesn’t Predicate2”
Of course, méi is used instead of bù if the verb is yªu.

Notice in the sentences below that in English we often don’t the verb if it is repeated in the second predicate. We also often leave out “only” or “just”, but the Chinese generally does not leave out zh•.
1. S/he only knows how to talk about it, not to do it.
2. This place only has coffee, but not tea.

This pattern is used to indicate that two different subjects have the same predicate, or that two different topics have the same comment:
S1 y¶ Predicate, S2 y¶ Predicate“Both S1 and S2 Predicate”
Topic1 y¶ Comment, Topic2 y¶ Comment“Both Topic1 and Topic2 Comment”
Be careful not to translate both y¶-s as “also”. You have to recognize that the pattern involves two y¶-s in Chinese, and translate using the “both…” pattern in English.

Lesson 8
(I) Imminent action with le (p. 103 #6)
There are a whole bunch of interchangeable patterns:
yào V le"about to V", "going to V soon"this is the most common one
also:"kuài V le", "kuàiyào V le", "jiùyào V le" (as we'll soon see, jiù indicates soonness)
If, instead of using a verb of action, you use an adjective, some verb of condition or state, or another description, it indicates that that condition is about to become true.
(II) Zài as main verb (pp. 101-102, #2)
N zài PW"N is located at PW"

Only a PW can come after zài — any noun that is put there becomes a place. For "it's with me" you can't say * zài wª, but have to say zài wª zhèr . Basically, you're turning the person into a place-word by putting zhèr or nàr after it.
(III) Existence in a place (p. 102, #3)
PW yªu N"There is N at PW" or "N exists at PW"
On the surface, this pattern seems to mean the same thing as
N zài PW"N is located at PW"
but in reality the two patterns have a different emphasis. In each of them the last part of the sentence is the main new information. That means the two patterns seem to differ in these ways:
answers the question assumes you already know something about
"PW yªu N" "What is there at PW?"PW
"N zài PW""Where is N?" N
If you want to ask where there are any Ns, you use the yªu pattern. There is also a third pattern:
PW shì N"The thing that is at PW is N", "N is what you will find at PW".
This means that the only thing at PW is N. It is different from "PW yªu N", which means only that there is N at PW, but there may be other things there, too.
This pattern is especially common as
PW d¢u shì N"There's nothing but N at PW", "PW is covered with N"
(IV) Stative verbs as adverbs (p. 103, #7)

Various stative verbs (adjectives) can precede main verbs. [Technical grammar point: I don't agree with the author that they are functioning as adverbs this way, because they don't delimit or qualify the action of the verb. Rather, the verb seems to be serving as a complement to the adjective — it specifies in what respect the subject of the sentence is "good" or "easy" or "enough" etc.]
h§o V"good to V", "pleasant to V", "easy to V",
róngyi V"easy to V"
nán V[opposite of "h§o V" and "róngyi V"]
gòu V"enough to V"
Only a small number of adjectives can be used this way, but many verbs can go with them. These adjectives can all also take bù.

The "coverb" (Chinese jiècí 'intermediary word') is a special word that allows an extra noun to be related to the verb, other than the main object. It is very much like the English preposition, and it is often (but not always) translated with a preposition. For example:
ChineseEnglish
coverb phraseprepositional phrase
a.g¶i n• V 'to V for you' ~ 'to V to you'
b.yòng Zh¢ngwén V 'to V in Chinese'
yòng b• V 'to V with a pen'
c. g™n péngyªu V'to V with a friend' (note: g™n X xué 'to learn from X")
d.dào Y£ngguó V'to V to England' (usually V is lái or qù)
e.zài M¶iguó V'to V in America'
zài zhu¢shàng V'to V on the table'
zài qìxiàngzhàn V'to V at the weather station'
zài fángzil• V'to V in the house'

Note that the translation of zài often depends on what kind of noun follows it — countries, cities, rooms, and buildings may need different English prepositions, and Chinese directional suffixes can also affect the choice of English preposition.
There are two critical differences between a Chinese coverb and an English preposition:

a. The coverb-plus-noun always comes before the verb it modifies (it is considered to be a type of adverb phrase, and adverbs always precede the verb they modify). Usually English prepositional phrases go after the verb.
b.A coverb is not a tiny particle like an English preposition — it is always a verb in its own right. When it is being used as a coverb it is subordinated to the real main verb of the sentence.

Beginning in Lesson 9, you will be exposed to many new coverbs. Try to keep them in mind as a class of words, in order to help remember how to use them. And notice that sometimes a single English word (such as in, with, and to, above, and for, below) may have any number of translations in Chinese. You must distinguish these carefully.
wèi'on behalf of ' ~ 'for'
tì'in place of' ~ 'for' , as a subsitute for, to replace for
g¶i'in the interests of' ~ 'for'

Lesson 9
•“ ji§. Coverbs (see pp. 111-112 of the text)

The "coverb" (Chinese jiècí 'intermediary word') is a special word that allows an extra noun to be related to the verb, other than the main object. It is very much like the English preposition, and it is often (but not always) translated with a preposition. For example:
ChineseEnglish
coverb phraseprepositional phrase
a.g¶i n• V 'to V for you' ~ 'to V to you'
b.yòng Zh¢ngwén V 'to V in Chinese'
yòng b• V 'to V with a pen'
c. g™n péngyªu V'to V with a friend' (note: g™n X xué 'to learn from X")
d.dào Y£ngguó V'to V to England' (usually V is lái or qù)
e.zài M¶iguó V'to V in America'
zài zhu¢shàng V'to V on the table'
zài qìxiàngzhàn V'to V at the weather station'
zài fángzil• V'to V in the house'

Note that the translation of zài often depends on what kind of noun follows it — countries, cities, rooms, and buildings may need different English prepositions, and Chinese directional suffixes can also affect the choice of English preposition.
There are two critical differences between a Chinese coverb and an English preposition:

a. The coverb-plus-noun always comes before the verb it modifies (it is considered to be a type of adverb phrase, and adverbs always precede the verb they modify). Usually English prepositional phrases go after the verb.
b.A coverb is not a tiny particle like an English preposition — it is always a verb in its own right. When it is being used as a coverb it is subordinated to the real main verb of the sentence.

Beginning in Lesson 9, you will be exposed to many new coverbs. Try to keep them in mind as a class of words, in order to help remember how to use them. And notice that sometimes a single English word (such as in, with, and to, above, and for, below) may have any number of translations in Chinese. You must distinguish these carefully.
Basic Chinese p. 64, PCG p.53, 65
wèi'on behalf of ' ~ 'for'
tì'in place of' ~ 'for' , as a subsitute for. to replace for
g¶i'in the interests of' ~ 'for'

§v j•. "D¢u" used to indicate plurality in a question (discussion p. 126, questions pp. 131-132)

When a question word is used as the object of the main verb, adding d¢u to the sentence lets the hearer know that you expect the answer to be in the plural. It doesn't matter whether the subject is in the plural or not — this d¢u pertains to the object, even though the object in the question is placed after the d¢u.
When the question word is shénme, some English speakers might say "what-all" if they intend a plural answer.

Colloquial Chinese Lesson 11. Grammar sentences from the Textbook
•“ ji§. cái/jiù (from pp. 144-145 and 153 in the textbook)
There are two basic ways of connecting phrases in Chinese: cái and jiù. They are radically different, and you need to make sure you understand the difference.
Both can be translated "then". However, if you remember jiù as "then immediately" and cái as "then and only then", their differences will be easier to keep straight.
Jiù indicates that something happens as soon as a certain condition is met.Cái indicates that something happens only after a certain condition is met.
Jiù indicates the soonness or earliness of what happens, or the smallness of some number to be reached. Cái emphasizes the lateness of what happens, or the largeness of some number to be reached.
Condition jiù Main Idea"right after Condition is met, Main Idea happens"
"Condition is met and then immediately Main Idea happens"
"as soon as Condition is met, Main Idea happens"
Condition cái Main Idea"only after Condition is met does Main Idea happen"
"not until Condition is met does Main Idea happen"
"Main Idea doesn't happen until Condition is met"
Here are two contrasting examples:
N• lái le wª jiù zªu"After you come, I will leave." [literally, "once you have come, then immediately I leave"]
N• lái le wª cái zªu"I won't leave until you come." [literally, "once you have come, only then I leave"]

Note that the English translation of the cái sentence contains the word won't — but the Chinese sentence has NO NEGATIVE PARTICLE! The word cái contains within itself the whole idea of English "not until", but in Chinese it's not a negative.
Also, note that the particle le here indicates "after" — remember, there is no past tense in Chinese.

The "Main Idea" part of the sentence can also take le — to indicate that the action is completed. But that's only true with jiù — with cái no completion-le is possible after the Main Idea. Why? Because cái emphasizes that the Main Idea begins after Condition is met, whereas le indicates that something is completed.
N• lái le wª jiù zªu le"After you come, I left." [literally, "once you came, then immediately I left and it's over and done with"]
N• lái le wª cái zªu"I didn't leave until you come." [literally, "once you came, only then did I leave ~ only then did my leaving begin"]
1a. S/he came at 9 — it was too early.
1b. S/he didn't come till 10 — it was too late.
2a. If s/he says it's okay, it's okay.
2b. It's not okay until s/he says it's okay.
3a. There aren't a lot of us["as for us, people are few"] — three bottles is about enough.
3b. There are a lot of us — no less than thirty bottles will be enough.
4a. This road is short ["near"] — we'll get there after walking just 10 minutes.
4b. This road is long — we won't get there until after walking 40 minutes.
5a. Before meeting, I guessed she was beautiful.
5b. Not until after meeting did I know she was beautiful.
6a. After we arrived there, s/he came in less than["not reaching to"] one minute.
6b. After we arrived there, s/he didn't come until we had waited 15 minutes.
7a. This matter is simple; s/he can attend to it. (S/he is not too capable.)
7b. This matter is not simple, only s/he can attend to it. (S/he is very capable.)
8a. S/he was full after eating only ["as little as"] half a bowl.
8b. S/he still isn't full after eating five bowls.
8c. S/he wan't full until after eating eight bowls.
9a. "Old Li hasn't left yet, eh?" "Yes, he's gone — he left yesterday."
9b. "Old Li has already left, eh?" "No, not yet — he doesn't leave until tomorrow.

§A y•. Duration of time

§˛ b•ng. Inclusiveness and exclusiveness "everything / everyone / everywhere / all the time" "anything / anyone / anywhere / any time" "nothing / no one / nowhere / no time"

Chinese doesn't have separate words for "everything / everyone / everywhere / all the time", "anything / anyone / anywhere / any time", or "nothing / no one / nowhere / no time" the way English does. Instead, we express these ideas with grammar patterns: We use question words plus d¢u.
ChineseEnglish
1. as object
Sshénme d¢uVSV everything / anything
Sshéi d¢uVSV everyone / anyone
2. as subject
shénme d¢uVeverything / anythingV
shéi d¢uVeveryone / anyoneV
3. as PW or TW
SQW-PWd¢uVSV everywhere / anywhere
SQW-TWd¢uVSVall TW / any TW
You make the negative forms of these sentences just by negating the verb (with bù or méi). In place of d¢u you can also use y¶ in the negative cases:
ChineseEnglish
1. as object
Sshénme d¢u/y¶ bù/méi VSdoesn't V anything SV nothing
Sshéi d¢u/y¶ bù/méi VSdoesn't V anyone SV no one
2. as subject
shénme d¢u/y¶ bù/méi VnothingV
shéi d¢u/y¶ bù/méi Vno oneV
3. as PW or TW
SQW-PWd¢u/y¶ bù/méi VSdoesn't V anywhere SV nowhere
SQW-TWd¢u/y¶ bù/méi VSdoesn't Vat any TW SVat no TW
1. What does she want to buy?

1b. S/he doesn't want to buy anything.

2a. Eveyone knows him/her.
2b. No one knows him/her.

4b. S/he said no day would be good — s/he won't permit us to go.
5. What did you do last night?
5a. I didn't do anything in particular — watched TV for two hours. (careful!)
5b. I didn't do anything at all — watched TV for two hours.
6. What can computers do for people?
Apart from not being able to eat and sleep for people, they can do anything.
One more pattern:
[S} z¶nme V d¢u ADJNo matter how S V, it's always ADJ.
7. Can s/he cook fish?
7a. Yes. No matter how s/he cooks it, it's delicious.

§B d£ng. Notes toward an overview of "verb-le" (li§o §F) — completed action
When must it be used?

1. When you are expressing that the action of a verb is complete or finished or has already taken place. It is regularly used with y•j£ng "already". Another hint that verb-le should be used is English "have/has V-ed", but unfortunately a lot of people don't use it much any more. We generally say "I ate 60 clams" rather than the grammatically correct "I have eaten 60 clams."

2. When the object of a completed verb is quantified — when you say how many times the action was done, or to how many of the object the action was done to. The reason is that enumerating the object in this way is really to specify how many times the action of the verb was completed.
3. In the first of two phrases connected by cái or jiù, where the meaning is "after [Phrase One], [Phrase Two]".
When must it not be used?

1. With stative verbs (adjectives), because they describe a condition or state, not an action that can be considered complete. If you do this, you will either sound as if you're using sentence le (new situation)
D¢ngxi guì le."Things have become expensive." ~ "Things are more expensive now."
N• duì le."You're right, now."
Rén h¶n du¢ le."There have gotten to be a lot of people now."
or else you will have turned the adjective into an action(!)
Píngguª guì le yìj£n yíkuài du¢."Apples have increased in price by more than one dollar per catty."
N• duì le s¡n'ge wèntí."You got three questions right."
Wªmen du¢ le yíge rén."We have become one person too many."
2. With verbs that describe some state or condition rather than an action, such as
shìequative, classifactory verb
zh£dao, x•hu¡n, d§suàn, etc.describe a mental state, not an action
xiàng, yªu, xìng, huì, pàdescribes a condition or continuous state

If a verb refers to some habitual or continuous action, it can't be said to be complete, and so verb-le isn't used. When in doubt, ask yourself: is the action of the verb a continuous state or something completed?

Danger: Note that if xi§ng means "to feel like" or "to have the opinion that…", it cannot take verb-le, but if it means "to perform the action of thinking" ~ "to miss", it is an action and can take verb-le. This is true of many other verbs you know — rènshi "to know ~ be acquainted with" describes a condition, but it can also mean "to get acquainted with", which is an action.
3. Le is ordinarilly not used with coverbs, only main verbs.
4. If a verb takes another verb after it, the first verb generally can't have verb-le attached:
SV1V2O
Wª zuóti¡njuédìngm§ijiº."I decided to buy some liquor yesterday."
T¡ qùniánk¡ish•xi¶xìn."S/he started writing a letter last year."
N•shu¢ n• huì tiàowº."You said you could dance."
In fact, if you narrate a series of events, you can leave off verb-le with them, because the sequence is more important that stressing that the action is complete.
5. Remember, verb-le is not used after a verb that has cái before it. But sentence-le could be.
Special cases:
1. When the action verb is negated. In that case, you use the special negative particle méi ®S, which means "didn't".
Wª méi qù"I didn't go." (My going didn't happen.)
L§osh£ méi gàosu wªmen."Teacher didn't tell us."
But remember, if it's not an action verb, you don't use le or méi — the negative form is simply bù V.
2. When the verb is a simple VO and the object is not quantified, it is more usual to use le twice, after both V and O. The first of these le is optional:
SV [le]O le
Wªch£ lefàn le."I have eaten." (My eating has happened and is completed.)
Wªch£ fàn le.(ditto)
N•menkàn lebào le."You've read the paper." (Your reading the paper is done.)
N•men kànbào le.(ditto)
Note that if you only use the first le and not the second, it sounds like you're setting up a cái or jiù sentence. So
Wªch£ lefàn
sounds like you're saying, "After I eat…" and the listener expects you to continue with something like
…jiù qù"…I'll go immediately."
…cái néng qù"…only then can I go."
3. If the object is quantified, using both verb-le and sentence-le give it the meaning "…so far" or "…up to now".
Wª qù le s¡ncì le.I've gone three times so far."
T¡men xué le li§ng nián le.They've been studying for two years.

•“ ji§. “Time elapsed” and “time within which”. Sentences from pp. 174-175, and grammar from pp. 167-168.

We have recently learned that if you mention the duration of some action or state, it is expressed as a time-phrase placed after the verb. That meansthat you’re tellhing how long the action or state persists for.
But if you want to tell how much time has passed since you last did something, you use a totally different pattern, in which the time-phrase is placed before the verb:
S TW bù V“S doesn’t V for/in TW”.
S yªu TW bù V(ditto)
S TW méi V“S hasn’t Ved for/in TW.” / “It’s been TW since S has Ved.”
S yªu TW méi V(ditto)

Notice that the méi pattern (the third and fourth ones) has two very different ways to be expressed in English: one negative (“hasn’t Ved”) and the other positive (“it’s been TW since”). Take precautious so that you don’t screw these things up.
Example:
T¡ yìti¡n méi t£ng lùy£n.S/he hasn’t listened to the recording in a whole day.
or: It’s been one day since she listened to the tapes.
L§osh£ m¶iti¡n yªu yíge zh¢ngtou bù shu¢huà.Every day, teacher doesn’t speak for one hour

You also place at time-phrase before the verb if you want to tell when something happened (as we’ve learned before), and also (as in the last lesson) if you want to tell a period of time within which some event happens some number of times.
S TW V #times O“S VO #times within TW.”
Example:

day. (= every day)

§A y•. “Indefinite past”, also known as the “experiential suffix”. Grammar pp. 166-167, sentences pp. 170-171.

We know that there is no past tense in Chinese, meaning that Chinese verbs can’t be made intrinsically to reflect the time something happened, the way English can say “is” vs. “was” or “eat” vs. “ate”. Instead, Chinese uses “aspect”, which indicates some restriction or delimitation on the action of the verb. For instance,
(1) an action that has been (or will be) completed, or done some fixed number of times, can be marked with V-le;
(2) a situation that is newly arrived at or represents some change or new situation can be indicated with sentence-le;

Both verb-le and sentence-le are examples of “aspect markers”, meaning that they indicate some limitation on the action or state of the verb. “Indefinite past” is also indicated with its own special aspect marker, the particle guo. Guo is the same as the word guò πL “to pass, cross”, but as an aspect marker it loses its tone in standard Mandarin.

Guo is always suffixed to an active verb. It indicates that the subject of the sentence has had the experience of whatever is described by the verb. The negative form involves méi, jsut as with verb-le.
Wª ch£guo Hánguó cài.`I have eaten Korean food.
(I’ve had that experience — it’s not new to me.
I’ve had Korean food before.
N• zuòguo f™ij£ ma?Have you been on an airplane?
(Have you ever had that experience?)
Have you ever flown on an airplane?
Have you flown before?
T¡men méi xuéguo Zh¢ngwén.They have never learned Chinese. (This esperience does not belong to them.)
They’ve never learned Chinese before.

Watch out! One way of indicating experiential aspect is with the word before, but you don’t want to translate this as y•qián! Another key word to look for is ever, although it is only used in questions. A third key phrase is have never. And also beware because English often uses “have” to indicate a completed action — so you can’t necessarily tell whether to use le or guo based on English alone — you have to think.

§˛ b•ng. Zài used as a verb complement (sentences, pp. 171-172; grammar pp. 168-169)

Complement? “Something that makes up a deficiency in something else.” A verb complement is something that completes the verb. In what way is my verb incomplete? Your verb is incomplete only because more information can be given about the action, and for that a complement is used.
In Chinese a complement differs from a modifier (such as an adverb) because the complement
1. comes after the verb, and
2. usually tells something about the the effect, result, or extent of the action of the verb.
When zai (usually toneless) is used to begin a complement, it indicates that as a result of the action of the verb, the subject or the object is being placed somewhere.
SV-zaiPW“S V so that S is located at PW”
Nínzhù-zain§r?“Where do you live?” lit., “You live so that you are situated where?”
Wªzuò-zaiy•zi shàng“I sit on the chair” lit, “I sit so that I end up situated on the chair”

How is this different from S zài PW V? It may seem exactly the same in English, but the sense of the Chinese is quite different. Choose your words carefully based on intended meaning in Chinese, not English.
Szài PWV“S performs the action of V at PW”
Nínzài n§rzhù?“Where do you live?” lit., “At what place do you live?”
Wªzài y•zi shàngzuò.“I sit on the chair” lit, “On the chair I perform the act of sitting.”

§B d£ng. The shi…de construction (“to bring out attendant circumstances”) (sentences, pp. 172-173, #5a; grammar, p. 167)

All things being equal, the verb is the most important part of the Chinese sentence. If you want to place special emphasis on the subject or one of the modifiers of the verb, you must use the shi…de pattern. It can even be used to modify the subject.
Sshi TWVdeS Ved at TW
Sshi PWVdeS Ved at PW
Sshi Cov-OVdeS Ved under the circumstances of Cov-O
shi SVdeIt was S who Ved

Note that shi is usually toneless in this pattern (at least in the textbook). This pattern is typically used in questions, with verbs describing actions that are already completed (although there are exceptions). No le is used in a shì…de sentence, however.

The shì serves to mark the thing being emphasized, but can itself be omitted. The de cannot be omitted. So when you see de at the end of a sentence, even if there’s no shì, you know that one of the modifiers of the verb is being emphasized.
1. “When did your uncle leave?” “He left last Wednesday.”
2. “Didn’t you come last September?” “No. I cam last August.”
3. “Have all these people come from the Soviet Unioin?” “Half are from the Soviet Union, half are from East Germany.”
4. “Was s/he born in England?” “No, but s/he attended both lower and middle school in England.”
5. “This sweater of yours is really beautiful — where did you buy it?” “It’s not beautiful. I bought it at that store in my neighborhood.”
6. “Where did you run into each other?” “At the entrance of the Peking Train Station. It was unexpected, I’d say.”
7. “How did you get here today?” “They came on foot”walked here”. I came by bike.”
8. “How did Old Wáng go?” “He went by boat.”
9. “Did you come with him/her?” “No, I came by myself.”
10. “In what year did s/he graduate?” (say, “in nineteen-seventy-what year”) “S/he graduated in ‘77.”
•≥ wù. Shì…de with object(sentences, pp. 173-174, #5b)

When the verb has an object, the de particle can go either before the object or at the very end of the sentence. If it goes before the object, it may sound strange to you, but this is nevertheless correct.
Sshì TWetc.VdeOS VO-ed at TW

13b. Look — these are the vegetables I bought in the morning.

•“ ji§. Predicative complements. Sentences from pp. 189-190, and grammar from pp. 187-188.
English often uses adverbs to describe how something is done. Chinese has adverbs, too, which go before the verb. But it is more common to use a “predicative complement” instead.

A predicative complement is a complement — something that goes after the verb, to complete it, and functions as a predicate. The meaning of the complement is to describe the result or effect of the verb. It works like this:
SVdeComplement
T¡shu¢deh¶n liúlì.She speaks with the effect/result of being clear.
= “S/he speaks fluently.”
SVOVdeComplement
Wª m¶iti¡n kànsh∞kànde h¶n g¡oxìng.Every day I read, and read with the effect/result of
being happy.”
= “Every day I read happily.”

Notice that in English we are still translating with an adverb. The Chinese, however, doesn’t use an adverb, and doesn’t have adverbial meaning. The complement is really the main message of the sentence, and so if someone asks you a question, the complement will contain the verb (active or stative) that you are supposed to use when you answer:
SVdeComplement
T¡shu¢deh¶n liúlì ma?answer: H¶n liúlì.orBù liúlì.
This pattern is really a type of Topic-Comment:
TOPICCOMMENT
SVOVdeComplement

The comment, remember, is the main message of the sentence. The topic merely sets up the situation. This kind of “topic” is far more complex looking than the ones you’ve seen before, but it’s basically the same idea:
TOPICCOMMENT
T¡shu¢deh¶n liúlì.“As for the way she speaks — [s/he’s] fluent.”
Wª m¶iti¡n kànsh∞kànde h¶n g¡oxìng.“As for my reading every day — [I’m] happy.”
Don’t try to translate it that way, though — no one will understand what you’re talking about. Use a regular English adverb — just remember that it’s not really an adverb in Chinese.
1. “Did s/he come early today?” “Yes. [S/he] came as early as 7.”
2. “Does s/he eat slowly?” “S/he doesn’t eat slowly, but [s/he] works slowly.”
3. “Where do you feel uncomfortable?” “There isn’t any discomfort, however these two past nights I haven’t slept too wellslept not too well”.
4. “Weren’t you at home yesterday?” “I took the kids up to the park. We played happilyplayed with the effect of being happy there.”
5. “It seems your energy level isn’t so good.” “Recently I’ve been too busy — [I’ve] been resting too littlenot enough.”
6. “As for this question, did s/he explain it clearlyexplain so that it was clear?” “S/he explained it extremely clearly.”
7. “How do you sing?” (= You, as for songs, sing them to what kind of effect?”)
“Sorry, I can’t sing any songs at all.”
8. “Does s/he drive well?” “[S/he] drives pretty well, it’s just that [s/he] drives on the fast siderelatively fast, and no one dares ride [with him/her].”
9. “Have you listened to the tape for Lesson 12?” “Yes, but it was not recorded well — it goes too slowly for a while, then too fast.”
10. “How does s/he cook Chinese food?” (i.e., well or badly) “S/he cooks both fast and well.”
11a. Those things s/he bought are all expensive.
11b. S/he paid a lot. (“he bought with the effect that they were expensive”)
12a. What s/he says, no one understood.
12b. S/he spoke very clearly.
§A y•. Intensifying complements. Sentences from pp. 190-191.
Another kind of complement is simply an intensive expression, which always follows an adjective (stative verb):
SSVdeComplement
Ti¡nqil¶ngdeh¶n."The weather is really cold."
Ti¡nqìl¶ngdebùdéli§o."The weather is really cold."
The complement jíle is used without de:
Ti¡nqil¶ngjíle."The weather is really cold."

The three forms above all have the same basic meaning. But it is also possible to put a whole sentence into the complement position, which has a meaning that basically belongs to the "effect/result" category:
SSVdeComplement"S is so SV that Complement."

Wªlèidebù g§n k¡ich™."I'm so tired I don't dare drive."
T¡menmángdewàngle dài háizi qù."They're so busy they forgot to bring the kids."
1. His/her luck is incredibly good. No sooner did s/he arrive at the station, when the train came. (pattern "no sooner than A did B happen" = g¡ng A jiù B)
2. This person's temperament is really weird. S/he never talks to other people.
3. Thethat movie I saw yesterday was really interesting.
4. His/her Chinese is extremely fluent. (use a result/extent complement meaning "his/her Chinese is spoken so that it is fluent in the extreme")
5. "How was it fooling around at Wáng's place on Saturday?" "We had a great time." (= "we played with the result of being happy in the extreme")
6. It's incredibly cold outside, and it's incredibly hot inside. Neither place feels good.
7. S/he says that to make this dish takes, at a minimum, three days. It's an incredible pain in the neck.
8. This person is really confused. No matter what you say to him/her, s/he always says, "Quite reasonable!" ("no matter what you say" = "[if] you say anything…d¢u")
9. Today [I] was busy for a whole dayfor fully a day. Now I'm so tired I no longer feel like doing anything.
10. That little girl, with her big eyes and little mouth, is so beautiful that "anyone who sees her loves her". ("person sees, person loves")
11. Not having eaten for two days, s/he is so hungry that s/he can't walk any more.
12. Yesterday the rain was so heavy"big" that there was no way for us to go out.
§˛ b•ng. Comparison. Sentences from pp. 191-193, grammar from pp. 187-188.
The basic pattern for a comparative sentence uses the coverb b•:
SCovOSV
T¡b•wªmàn.“S/he is slower than me.” ~ “S/he is slower than I am.”
It is the coverb, rather than the adjective (SV) that gets negated:
T¡bù b•wªmàn.“S/he is not slower than me.” ~ “S/he is not slower than I am.”

Don’t forget that in a complement of extent or result (such as we practiced at the beginning of this handout), it is really the last part of the sentence that holds the main message, so that is also where negation takes place:
SVdeComplement Cov-O2 SV
T¡shu¢deb• wªliúlì.She speaks with the effect/result of being more clear than me.
= “S/he speaks more fluently than I do.”
SVOVdeComplement........... Cov-O2 SV
Wª m¶iti¡n kànsh∞kànde b• shéi d¢u g¡oxìng.Every day I read, and read with the effect/result of being happier than anyone else.”
= “Every day I read more happily than anyone else.”

Those are the basic patterns. Notice that the coverb-object phrase always comes before the thing it modifies, in this case the stative verb. The book also lists two other patterns, where a VO is used. In the first example, instead of repeating the verb, you just prepose the object:
SOVdeComplement........... Cov-O2 SV
Wª sh∞m¶iti¡n kànde b• shéi d¢u g¡oxìng.Every day I read with the effect/result of being happier than anyone else.”
= “Every day I read more happily than anyone else.”
In the second, the coverb-object phrase modify the verb on its second appearance:
SVOCov-O2VdeSV
Wª m¶iti¡n kànsh∞b• shéi d¢u kànde g¡oxìng.Every day I read, and read with the effect/result of being happier than anyone else.”
= “Every day I read more happily than anyone else.”
Here the coverb-object phrase must be modifying the second appearance of the verb, because that is what it precedes.
Notice that the d¢u stays right after the coverb-object phrase because b• shéi d¢u “than anyone else” forms a unit.
1. “Is Chinese harder than English?” ““They’re about the same — neither one is easy.”
2. “Is s/he both taller and plumper than you?” “S/he is taller than me but not plumper.”
3. “Which of these two houses is better?” (“as for these two houses, which is better?”) “It’s hard to say. This one is bigger than that one, but that one’s more beautiful than this one.”
4. “Of that husband and wife, whose personality is better?” “The husband’s personality is better than the wife[’s].” (notice that Chinese says “than the wife”)
5. “Who would it be better to have go and attend to this matter?” (= “as for this matter, it would be better for who to go and attend to it?”) “It would be better for you to go than him/her.”
6. “Does s/he run faster than you?” “S/he runs faster than anyone else.” (two ways to say it are listed)
7. “Is Younger Brother smarter than Elder Brother?” “Yes. Younger Brother learns both faster and better than Elder Brother.”
8. “Why are you always more tired than other people?” “I don’t sleep as much as they do.” (use an extent/result complement)
9. “You play cards well, eh?” “I’m not particularly good at cards. They all play better than I do.”
10. “Does s/he write good letters?” (= write letters well) “[S/he] writes extremely interestingly, better than any of us.”
11. “Did both of them answer this question?” “Yes. Elder Sister answered more clearly than Younger Sister.”
12. “Why do you sell [things] more expensively than other people?” “Our things are better than other people[‘s]” (notice that Chinese says “than other people”)
§B d£ng. Comparison with gèng and hái. Sentences from p. 192.
If you want to add the idea of “even more so” to a comparison, place gèng or hái before the adjective:
SCovOhái/gèngSV“S is even more SV than O.”
T¡ dìdib•t¡gèngg¡o.“His little brother is even taller than he is.”
1. You’re smarter than I am, but s/he is even smarter than you.
2. You’ve spoken well, however s/he makes even more sense than you do.
3. Speaking Chinese is already enough of a nuisance. Writing characters is even more of a nuisance than speaking Chinese.
4. “Is Dr. Wáng the most famous doctor in London?” “No, Dr. L• is even more famous.”
5. “S/he forgets faster than you do, but I forget faster than s/he does.”
6. S/he’s both smart and hard-working, and speaks Chinese even better than Chinese people.
7. His/her younger brother rides [a bike] even faster than a car.
8. S/he has learned this character three hundred times and still doesn’t know it. S/he is really something! Dumber than an ox!
•≥ wù. Degrees of comparison. Sentences from pp. 192-3.
There are various complements of extent that can be used with comparisons, if you want to say how much more.
SCovOSVComplement
T¡b•wªpàngyìdi§nr.“S/he is a little plumper than me.”
T¡b•wªpàngde du¢.“S/he is much plumper than me.”
T¡b•wªpàngdu¢le.“S/he is much plumper than me.”
T¡b•wªpàngb¡ g¢ngj£n.“S/he is eight kilograms plumper than me.”
Most do not use de, but the complement de du¢ is an exception. Notice that in English we use adverbs (before the adjective, and modifying it) to express this meaning.
1. “Do you think its better to live upstairs or downstairs?” “Probably living upstairs is a little better (than living upstairs).”
2. “Is the window in front or the window in back bigger?” “The one in front is a little bigger (than the one in back).”
3. “Which of the two of you speaks English more fluently?” “S/he is much more fluent (with regard to speaking) than I am.”
4. “Are you smarter than him/her?” “No, no, no — I’m much dumber than him/her.”
5. “Today is a little colder than yesterday, isn’t it?” “Today is much colder than yesterday!”
6. “Did s/he write better than in the past?” “Much worse than in the past — there’s no comparison.”
7. “How many years older than your younger sister are you?” “Only one year and three months older”
8. “Is your watch fast?” “It’s not fast. It’s two minutes slower than the school’s clock.”
9. “How much more expensive is this kind than that kind?” “A buck and a half more.”
10. “How much more money does s/he have than you?” (the English word “have” does not translate directly) “$12 more per month.”
11. “S/he has taught for longer than you, I suppose.” “That’s right. S/he has taught for a little longer than I have.”
12. “Your little brother is”has grown” taller than you, eh?” “He’s much taller, a whole head taller than me.”
13. “Does s/he still run slowly?” “Recently s/he has been practicing running every day, and runs much faster than before.”
14. “Does s/he explain clearly?” “Yes, very. Much clearer than the teacher does.”
§v j•. Inclusiveness, with the lián…y¶/d¢u pattern. Sentences from p. 193. Grammar omitted.

When you want to show that the verb has a very wide scope, so wide that any and all subjects do it, you use the lián…d¢u/y¶ pattern. In English you say “even”; in Chinese, you place lián before the subject being stressed and use d¢u or y¶ in the normal place that d¢u or y¶ go. Lián means “linking, connecting”.
LiánSd¢u/y¶VO
Lián t¡men d¢uzh£dàozhèi jiàn shì."Even they know about this matter."
Lián n•y¶huì chàngg™r.“Even you can sing.”

So lián is a good translation for English “even”. Unfortunately, it can sometimes be omitted, and just d¢u or y¶ used to bear the whole meaning. That is much trickier, because you don’t necessariliy know whether the meaning is “even” or “all”/“also”.
Sd¢u/y¶VO
T¡men d¢uzh£dàozhèi jiàn shì."Even they know about this matter." or “They all know about this matter.”
N•y¶huì chàngg™r.“Even you can sing.” or “You can sing, too.”
From now on, when you see d¢u or y¶ in a sentence, you have to at least consider the possibility that lián is implied.

Lián…d¢u/y¶ can also be used with the verb’s scope is so wide that it acts on any and all objects. In that case, the object is placed somewhere before the verb. Lián always goes right before the thing you’re drawing into the scope. But notice than in English, “even” usually goes before the verb, even though it acts on the object.
SliánOd¢u/y¶V
N£ lián zhèige zìd¢ubúhuì xi¶."You don’t even know how to write this character." (better) "You don’t know how to write even this character.”
Wªliánbùshªu y¶xuéguo.“I’ve even learned the radicals.” (better) “I’ve learned even the radicals.”
The same meaning can be expressed with lián O before the subject:
LiánOSd¢u/y¶V
Lián zhèige zìn£ d¢ubúhuì xi¶."You don’t even know how to write this character."
Liánbùshªu wªy¶xuéguo.“I’ve even learned the radicals.”
If the sentence is negative, sometimes the object is enumerated by “one” or “half of one” to show the meaning “not even a single one”.
(Lián)OSd¢u/y¶V
(Lián) yíge zìn£ d¢ubúhuì xi¶."You don’t even know how to write a single character."
There are also ways of using this pattern to stress the wideness of the conditions under which a verb occurs (or, especially, doesn’t occur), and to stress the verb itself.
SliánCov-Od¢u/y¶V
T¡ (lián)zuòch™d¢ubúk¶n qù."S/he is not even willing to go by car."
S(lián)Vd¢u/y¶Aux
T¡ (lián) k¡ich™d¢uhuì."S/he even knows how to drive." Note: in a sense, Aux V seems to be behaving like V O here: “Even driving s/he knows how to.”
S(lián)Vd¢u/y¶Neg-Vrepeated
Wª(lián)t£ng y¶méi t£ngguo.“I’ve never even heard [of it].” Note: this pattern is ordinarily only used in the negative.

One other thing: the English expressions “even if” and “even though” are in no way related to the “even” in these sentences. They use special words of their own (su£rán can be used for “even though”, and jísh• can be used for “even if”). But you may hear Chinese speakers saying plain “even” for all three in their English. This sounds really awful. Help them.

1. A stative verb indicates a state of affairs rather than an action or an event.
Its function is not exactly like an adjective in English, in that it doesn’t require a verb “to be”.
2. A stative verb is modified by a degree adverb, most commonly
h¶n

4. If both h¶n and bù are present, the word order becomes important to the meaning.

Wª lèi, t¡ bú lèi. T¡ rè, wª bú rè.

d¢u pattern
“As for O1 O2 O3, I read all of them.
中文書、法文書、英文書，我都看。
他中國菜、法國菜，都不愛吃。
喝法國酒、吃中國菜，誰不喜歡？
As for drinking French wine and eating Chinese food, who wouldn’t like that?
Dou “all” “both” always refers back to a preceding phrase, e.g. the subject, a posed topic, a freqency expression (e.g. with m¶i “every”). It never relates to what follows it or follows the verbs.
Students are all very busy and the teachers are all very busy too now.
Are the jobs that do not all very easy either?
Isn’t it true that people without money all like good books also?
I do Taichi everyday.
The adverb d¢u suggests inclusiveness. It refers to the preceeding words, and therefore must be used at the end of an enumeration.Intergrated.C p.50

By adding le to a sentence, implying a commiment or circumstances have changed or are about to change, that things are not as listener expects, or that circumstances have reached a particular point. When using le in this way, the speaker readily lets his/her enthusiasm, interst and involvement be kknown. Sentence le does occur in written Chinese, especiallly in letters, but its function makes it particularly common in speach. In effect, adding sentence le updates the situation; thus underlying all such statements with le is the fundamental notion of change.
1) Sentence with verbs or indicators which mean ‘begin’, ‘end’, ‘start’, ‘finish’, ‘emerge’, ‘disappear’, ‘change’, etc, which by definition introduce new circumstance.
T¡ bù ch¢u y¡n le.
2) Sentence with a monosyllabic action or state verb which naturally poses a contradiction to a previous action or state:
T¡ pàng le.T¡ lèi le.
3) Sentences which have nominal predicates indicating age, height, weight, etc., and register change or updating:
Wª j£nnián liùshí suì le.
Wª q£shí g¢ngj£n le.
When le follows a verb phrase at the end of a sentence, it often functions both as aspect marker indicating complted action and as sentence particle:
D¢ngti¡n guò qù le.
Sentence le is usually not used where the indication of ‘change’ is not the speaker’s primary concern.
1) Sentence which indicate habitual actions, where the emphasis is more on persistence than change:
T¡ chángchang d§ tàijíchuán.
2) Sentence with verbs marked by a continuous aspect marker or brief duration indicator, where the focus is on the continuity or brevity of the action:
T¡ zài t£ng x£nwén.
3) Sentences with verbs complemented by duration or frequency indicators or used with objects qualified by jumeral and measure word phrases, where the interest is in what took place:

d¢u, y¶, jiù always come after the subject.

gòu
The word gòu basically meas “enough” However, it cannot be used in front of a noun; therefore to say “enough money” in Chinese we must say qián gòu (lit. “money is enough”).

有一天，王先生、王太太請幾個美國朋友吃飯。王太太這個人跟很多中國人一樣客氣。上菜了，王太太說：真對不起！今天沒（有）什麼好菜，我這個人不太會做菜。這幾個菜都做得不怎麼好。這隻雞太老了，這兩條魚有一點兒生。青菜不夠好，這個湯也有點兒冷了。真對不起！請大家不要客氣，還是多吃一點兒吧！
那幾位外國客人，你看我，我看你，不知道為什麼八個菜跟一個湯還說太少；也不知道菜不好吃為什麼還要叫客人多吃。你知道為什麼嗎？要是你是王太太，你也會這麼說嗎？
